newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian sugar sheds gains, buyers back off.
newsitem.headline: Indian sugar sheds gains, buyers back off.

text.p: Indian sugar prices weakened on Thursday, shedding some gains made earlier this week as demand dried up and speculation emerged the government may release extra sugar onto the market, traders said.
"Market jumped up in the recent days following price hike of the sugar supplied through public distribution system by government but today demand resistance capped rally," one said.
Fear that government may release extra free sale quota also prompted light profit-taking. The quota for February is 700,000 tonnes while it was 650,000 tonnes in January.
In ready delivery sugar S-30 fell by 9/15 rupees to 1,265/1,296 rupees per quintal while M-30 moved down by 5/8 rupees to 1,305/1,392 rupees per quintal.
Sugar was up by 5/10 rupees per quintal on Wednesday.
Sugar mill delivery remained untraded today as most of the delivery tenders out of the free sale quota for the first half of current month are exhausted.
